title: confusing error with enum tuple variants (?)

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
Given the following code: https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=a64e2483bff9d381415ffda6ed42d1ff

```rust
#[derive(Debug)]
enum Test {
    Variant(u8),
}

fn main() {
    let x = Test::Variant;
    println!("{:?}", x);
}
```

The current output is:

```
error[E0277]: `fn(u8) -> Test {Test::Variant}` doesn't implement `Debug`
 --> src/main.rs:8:22
  |
8 |     println!("{:?}", x);
  |                      ^ `fn(u8) -> Test {Test::Variant}` cannot be formatted using `{:?}` because it doesn't implement `Debug`
  |
  = help: the trait `Debug` is not implemented for `fn(u8) -> Test {Test::Variant}`
  = note: required by `std::fmt::Debug::fmt`
  = note: this error originates in a macro (in Nightly builds, run with -Z macro-backtrace for more info)
```

Hi! When I came across this error, I had forgotten that the enum variant I was using was a tuple because it was in a different file that I hadn't looked at in a while. The `fn(u8) -> Test { Test::Variant }` notation threw me off and is _very_ difficult to search for. Some indication that this error is related to tuple enum variants, displaying the declaration of the variant in question, and/or giving more searchable terms might be more helpful? Thanks!
